channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 The New York Times Company

item.title: Miscalculation Led to Escalation in Clash Between Israel and Iran
item.description: Israeli officials say they didn’t see a strike on a high-level Iranian target in Syria as a provocation, and did not give Washington a heads-up about it until right before it happened.
item.dc:creator: Ronen Bergman, Farnaz Fassihi, Eric Schmitt, Adam Entous and Richard Pérez-Peña
item.media:description: The Iranian Embassy complex in Damascus, Syria, a day after an airstrike by Israel.

item.title: In Ukraine With Soldiers From the International Legion
item.description: Our photographer spent four days at a remote Ukrainian trench outpost manned by soldiers who signed up from abroad.
item.dc:creator: Tyler Hicks
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier after firing a rocket-propelled grenade at a Russian position in the Serebrianka Forest.

item.title: U.S. Reimposes Oil Sanctions on Venezuela as Hopes Dim for Free Election
item.description: The Biden administration had temporarily lifted sanctions after President Nicolás Maduro agreed to make free elections possible. Now Mr. Maduro has put up barriers to a credible vote.
item.dc:creator: Genevieve Glatsky
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Nicolás Maduro after signing up as a candidate for Venezuela’s presidential elections.

item.title: Netanyahu Says Israel Will Make Its Own Decisions in Response to Iran’s Attack
item.description: “We will make our own decisions,” said Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, rebuffing European diplomats’ requests to stand down.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Michael Levenson
item.media:description: Members of the Israeli military showing the remnants of an Iranian ballistic missile that fell on Israel over the weekend.

item.title: Russian Missile Attack North of Kyiv Kills at Least 17, Ukraine Says
item.description: President Volodymyr Zelensky said the death toll might rise and blamed lack of air defenses for the loss of life. Dozens more were reported wounded.
item.dc:creator: Maria Varenikova and Marc Santora
item.media:description: The site of a building destroyed by a Russian missile strike, according to Ukrainian officials, in Chernihiv, Ukraine, on Wednesday.

item.title: How London Became a ‘Hot Spot’ for Threats Against Iranian Journalists
item.description: Iranian reporters and broadcasters in Britain have suffered physical attacks, threats and surveillance, a report by Reporters Without Borders said, weeks after a newscaster was stabbed in London.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia

item.title: Mount Ruang Volcano Erupts in Indonesia, Forcing Hundreds to Evacuate
item.description: Hundreds of earthquakes were detected in the weeks preceding the eruption of the volcano in North Sulawesi province. Hundreds of people were evacuated.
item.dc:creator: Christine Hauser
item.category: State University of New York at Buffalo

item.title: Nine People, Including Air Canada Worker, Arrested in $14.5 Million Gold Heist
item.description: The stolen gold was partly used to buy guns that were bound for Canada, the police said.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Arlyn Mcadorey/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Nick Milinovich, the deputy chief of the Peel Regional Police, speaking on Wednesday about arrests in connection with last year’s theft of gold bars and bank notes at Toronto Pearson Airport.

item.title: What Can ‘Green Islam’ Achieve in Indonesia?
item.description: Clerics in Indonesia are issuing fatwas, retrofitting mosques and imploring congregants to help turn the tide against climate change.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee and Ulet Ifansasti
item.media:description: Inspecting solar panels that provide electrical power to Istiqlal Mosque in December in Jakarta, Indonesia.

item.title: Aung San Suu Kyi Moved to Unknown Location Amid Heat Wave
item.description: The unexpected relocation was attributed to a heat wave, and came as the military government is facing increasingly emboldened rebel forces.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee
item.media:credit: Koen Van Weel/ANP, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Daw Aung San Suu Kyi in 2019. The ousted former leader of Myanmar was relocated from prison this week to an unknown location.

item.title: A Timeline of Britain’s Troubled Plan to Send Asylum Seekers to Rwanda
item.description: The U.K. government hoped to pass a bill this week, two years after the plan was first unveiled, in an effort to override a ruling by Britain’s highest court.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: A protest against the British government’s plan to deport asylum seekers to Rwanda, outside the Home Office, in central London, in December.

item.title: Heavy Rain and Floods Kill 19 in Oman and Disrupt Dubai Airport
item.description: A year’s worth of rain fell in one day in some areas across Oman and the United Arab Emirates, bringing cities to a standstill.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:description: Men gesture trying to tow a vehicle out of standing water in Dubai, United Arab Emirates, on Tuesday. Heavy rains lashed the Emirates on Tuesday, flooding major highways and leaving vehicles abandoned on roadways across Dubai.

item.title: Ukraine’s Big Vulnerabilities: Ammunition, Soldiers and Air Defense
item.description: The shortages add up to a dire situation for Ukraine in the third year of the war, presenting commanders with near impossible choices on how to deploy limited resources.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: A member of Ukraine’s 17th Tank Brigade near the front line in the Donetsk region in January.

item.title: Mayor Orders Police to Interrupt Conservative Conference in Brussels
item.description: A mayor in Brussels gave no explanation of why he thought it necessary to try to stop a conservative gathering from taking place, other than saying he wanted to “guarantee public safety.”
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:description: Belgian police blocking the entrance of the Claridge, where the National Conservatism Conference was being held in Brussels on Tuesday.

item.title: Thursday Briefing
item.description: Europe asks Israel for restraint on Iran.
item.dc:creator: Daniel E. Slotnik
item.media:description: Members of the Israeli military showing the remnants of an Iranian ballistic missile that fell on Israel over the weekend.

item.title: Björn Höcke of the AfD Goes on Trial in Germany
item.description: Björn Höcke, one of the most prominent far-right figures in Germany, has called the trial an attempt to suppress patriotism.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon
item.media:description: Björn Höcke heads the far-right Alternative for Germany party in the state of Thuringia.

item.title: How A.I. Tools Could Change India’s Elections
item.description: Avatars are addressing voters by name, in whichever of India’s many languages they speak. Experts see potential for misuse in a country already rife with disinformation.
item.dc:creator: Suhasini Raj
item.media:credit: Ahmer Khan for The New York Times

item.title: Thursday Briefing: Israel Seems Poised to Retaliate
item.description: Also, a deadly Russian missile strike in Ukraine and “green Islam” in Indonesia.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Ilia Yefimovich/picture-alliance, via dpa, via Associated Press Images
item.media:description: The top diplomats from Germany and Britain met with the Israeli president, Isaac Herzog (middle), in Jerusalem yesterday.

item.title: Long-Acting Drugs May Revolutionize H.I.V. Prevention and Treatment
item.description: New regimens in development, including once-weekly pills and semiannual shots, could help control the virus in hard-to-reach populations.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.media:credit: Grant Hindsley for The New York Times
item.media:description: Kenneth Davis, a patient in an H.I.V. treatment trial, undergoes a routine exam with the assistance of Phoebe Bryson-Cahn, a research clinician, at Harborview Medical Center in Seattle.

item.title: UN Report Describes Abuse and Dire Conditions in Israeli Detention
item.description: Some Palestinians recounted being beaten with metal bars or the butts of guns, according to the report. Israeli officials have said that the rights of detainees are respected.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
United Nations Relief and Works Agency
item.media:description: Israeli soldiers with Palestinian detainees in Gaza in December. The Israeli military reviewed this image as part of the conditions of allowing the photographer to accompany soldiers.

item.title: Hezbollah Attack Injures 14 Israeli Soldiers in Border Village
item.description: The Lebanese militant group said the drone and missile attack was in response to Israeli airstrikes that killed two Hezbollah commanders.
item.dc:creator: Euan Ward, Ronen Bergman and Adam Rasgon
item.media:description: An Israeli soldier near Arab al-Aramashe in northern Israel after a strike by Hezbollah on Wednesday.

item.title: Israel Will Respond to Iran’s Attack, Cameron Says
item.description: Top diplomats from Germany and Britain traveled to Jerusalem to urge Israel not to respond in a way that risked a wider regional conflict.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:description: From left, Annalena Baerbock, Germany’s foreign minister; Isaac Herzog, Israel’s president; and David Cameron, Britain’s foreign secretary, at a hotel in Jerusalem on Wednesday.

item.title: Inflation in U.K. Slows to 3.2%, Lowest in More Than 2 Years
item.description: As the economy cools, pressure is building on the Bank of England to cut interest rates.
item.dc:creator: Gregory Schmidt

item.title: Israel’s Offensive in Gaza: An Update on Where the Conflict Stands
item.description: More than six months after the Hamas-led attacks of Oct. 7, Israel’s campaign to eliminate the armed group in Gaza is pressing ahead.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:description: Buildings destroyed in Khan Younis, in southern Gaza, on Tuesday.

item.title: Israel ponders a response to Iran’s attack, with each choice a risk.
item.description: In debating how to respond to last weekend’s Iranian airstrike, Israel’s war cabinet is choosing between options that could deter future attacks or de-escalate hostilities.
item.dc:creator: Ronen Bergman, Isabel Kershner, Julian E. Barnes and Russell Goldman
item.media:description: An Israeli tank on the Gaza border.

item.title: Wednesday Briefing
item.description: Israel’s difficult choices on Iran.
item.dc:creator: Daniel E. Slotnik
item.media:description: “We cannot stand still from this kind of aggression,” said Rear Adm. Daniel Hagari, standing next to one of the Iranian ballistic missiles Israel intercepted over the weekend.

item.title: The Global Turn Away From Free-Market Policies Worries Economists
item.description: More countries are embracing measures meant to encourage their own security and independence, a trend that some say could slow global growth.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Cohen
item.media:description: Kristalina Georgieva, managing director of the International Monetary Fund, has pushed back against the growing use of industrial policies.

item.title: Why Elections Take So Long in India
item.description: The election is a giant undertaking that requires millions of poll workers, voting machines and security forces to cover deserts, mountains, forests and megacities.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon and Hari Kumar
item.media:credit: R. Satish Babu/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A poll official working on electronic voting machines at a distribution center.

item.title: Israel Weighs Response to Iran Attack, With Each Choice a Risk
item.description: In debating how to respond to last weekend’s Iranian airstrike, Israel’s war cabinet is choosing between options that could deter future attacks or de-escalate hostilities, but all carry drawbacks.
item.dc:creator: Ronen Bergman, Isabel Kershner, Julian E. Barnes and Russell Goldman
item.media:description: An Israeli tank on the Gaza border.

item.title: A Year’s Worth of Rain Fell in Dubai on a Single Day
item.description: The United Arab Emirates had its largest rainfall in 75 years as a year’s worth of rain fell in Dubai alone, temporarily halting flights. More rain is expected into Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: Aimee Ortiz
item.media:description: The deluge dumped nearly five inches of rain in Dubai by Tuesday evening, or about as much as the United Arab Emirates typically receives in a year.

item.title: Wednesday Briefing: China’s Economy Grew Faster Than Expected
item.description: Plus, Australia’s feral cat problem.
item.dc:creator: Justin Porter
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Qilai Shen for The New York Times
item.media:description: A clothing store in Shenzhen. Retail sales in China have picked up.

item.title: High Winds Scuttle Burning of Snowman in Zurich, Disappointing the Swiss
item.description: The burning of the effigy known as the Böögg is the finale of Sechseläuten, an annual spring festival akin to Groundhog Day. The normally stoic Swiss wallowed in disappointment.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.media:description: The ceremonial burning of a pyre topped with a fake snowman whose head is packed with fireworks is the centerpiece of Sechseläuten, Zurich’s spring festival. On Monday, the burning was called off because of strong winds.

item.title: U.S. Lays Out Protections for Assange if He Is Extradited
item.description: American officials sought to reassure the U.K. about Julian Assange’s treatment should the former WikiLeaks founder, who has been indicted by the U.S., be sent there.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:description: Julian Assange, 52, was the head of WikiLeaks in 2010 when it published tens of thousands of classified military and diplomatic documents leaked by Chelsea Manning, an Army intelligence analyst.

item.title: U.S. Plans New Sanctions on Iran
item.description: The U.S. treasury secretary, Janet Yellen, said that sanctions could be announced “in the coming days” and would likely focus on oil exports and imports of military hardware.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport
item.media:credit: Solmaz Daryani for The New York Times
item.media:description: Oil and gas infrastructure in Khuzestan Province, Iran.

item.title: Beijing Race Under Scrutiny As Video Suggests Runners Helped Chinese Winner
item.description: Organizers are investigating the results of the Beijing Half Marathon, after three runners from Kenya and Ethiopia appeared to wave a Chinese competitor past them before the finish.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:description: Chinese runner He Jie, Ethiopian Dejene Hailu Bikila and Kenyans Robert Keter and Willy Mnangat taking part in a half-marathon in Beijing on Sunday.

item.title: UN Panel Says Israel Is Obstructing Its Investigation of the Oct. 7 Attack
item.description: The commission, which is looking at possible human rights violations by Hamas and Israel, said it had still amassed large amounts of evidence. Israel has accused the commission of bias.
item.dc:creator: Nick Cumming-Bruce
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: Navi Pillay, right, who leads a U.N. commission created to look into possible human rights violations by Israel, with the Egyptian ambassador to the U.N., Ahmed Ihab Abdelahad Gamaleldin, in Geneva on Tuesday.

item.title: The 2024 Paris Olympics Prepares For Cyberattacks
item.description: “We will be attacked,” the official responsible for fending off cyberthreats said. To prepare, organizers have been hosting war games and paying “bug bounties” to hackers.
item.dc:creator: Tariq Panja
item.media:description: The head of cyberattack preparations for the 2024 Paris Olympics said he expected to face billions of probing attacks against the Games’ computer networks.

item.title: Copenhagen’s Old Stock Exchange Building Partly Collapses in Fire
item.description: The 17th-century building, one of the city’s best-known structures, was once the financial center of Denmark.
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor and Maya Tekeli
item.media:credit: Emil Helms/Ritzau Scanpix, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Smoke billowing from the stock exchange building in Copenhagen on Tuesday.

item.title: For Israel’s Allies, Iranian Missile Strike Scrambles Debate Over Gaza
item.description: Israel’s restless allies have voiced anger over the death toll in Gaza, but when their archnemesis launched a missile barrage, they set it aside. At least for the moment.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: A rocket booster that fell near Arad, Israel, after Iran launched drones and missiles over the weekend.

item.title: Germany’s Leader, Olaf Scholz, Walks a Fine Line in China
item.description: Chancellor Olaf Scholz tried to promote German business interests while delivering warnings from Europe about trade and geopolitical tensions.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson and Melissa Eddy
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Michael Kappeler/dpa/Picture Alliance, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Chancellor Olaf Scholz of Germany with Xi Jinping, China’s leader, in Beijing on Tuesday.

item.title: Tuesday Briefing
item.description: A chance for U.S. aid to Ukraine and Israel.
item.dc:creator: Daniel E. Slotnik
item.category: New York State Criminal Case Against Trump (71543-23)
item.media:description: The aid package that Mike Johnson is advancing mirrors the $95 billion aid bill the Senate passed two months ago.

item.title: Microsoft Makes High-Stakes Play in Tech Cold War With Emirati A.I. Deal
item.description: Microsoft said it would invest $1.5 billion in G42, an Emirati company with ties to China, as Washington and Beijing maneuver to secure tech influence in the Persian Gulf.
item.dc:creator: Paul Mozur and David E. Sanger
item.media:credit: Grant Hindsley for The New York Times

item.title: Israel Weighs Response to Iran’s Attack as Allies Push for Restraint
item.description: The Israeli war cabinet met again on Monday to discuss the strike, with some hawkish members of the prime minister’s government calling for a swift and forceful retaliation.
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Vinograd, Isabel Kershner and Michael Levenson
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Demonstrators gathering in Tehran on Monday to show their support for Iran’s attack on Israel.

item.title: Israeli Settlers Kill Two Palestinian Men in the West Bank, Officials Say
item.description: The Israeli military said the men were killed during a “violent exchange” that followed a report of a Palestinian attacking an Israeli shepherd.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman
item.media:description: Burned vehicles in the Palestinian village of Al Mughayir, in the West Bank, on Saturday.

item.title: Tuesday Briefing: Donald Trump’s Trial Begins
item.description: Also, Israel weighs a response to Iran and Sudan marks a year of war.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Jefferson Siegel for The New York Times
item.media:description: Former President Donald J. Trump in Manhattan court on Monday.

item.title: Lebanese Official Blames Israel’s Spy Agency for Killing Near Beirut
item.description: The U.S. had accused the dead man of being a financial middleman between Hamas and Iran. The interior minister said there were suggestions that the killing “was carried out by intelligence services.”
item.dc:creator: Euan Ward
item.media:description: Lebanon’s interior minister, Bassam Mawlawi, said initial findings suggested that the killing of a money changer “was carried out by intelligence services.”

item.title: Expert Panel Calls on Germany to Legalize Abortion in First 12 Weeks
item.description: For decades, Germany allowed early abortions even while keeping them illegal. A government-appointed commission says the system is “untenable.”
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon
item.media:description: From left, Lisa Paus, the German minister for family affairs, senior citizens and women and youth; Karl Lauterbach, the health minister; and Marco Buschmann, the justice minister, at a news conference in Berlin on Monday.

item.title: Pro-Palestinian Protests Block Golden Gate Bridge and Other U.S. Hubs
item.description: The coordinated protests across the United States and around the globe were planned in part to coincide with Tax Day in the United States.
item.dc:creator: Colbi Edmonds
item.media:credit: Brontë Wittpenn/San Francisco Chronicle, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Pro-Palestinian protesters shutting down traffic on I-880 in Oakland, Calif., on Monday.

item.title: Britain’s Leaders Condemn Iran’s Attacks but Urge Israel to Show Restraint
item.description: Rishi Sunak said the government in Tehran was “intent on sowing chaos” in the region, but he also called for restraint from “all sides.”
item.dc:creator: Stephen Castle
item.media:description: Prime Minister Rishi Sunak recording a statement on Iran’s attack on Israel, in London on Sunday.

item.title: Ukraine Sees ‘Hypocrisy’ After Western Allies Helped Intercept Iran’s Attack on Israel
item.description: The U.S., British and French militaries helped intercept Iranian missiles and drones, but Ukrainians say they haven’t provided the same help against Russian air attacks.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Matthew Mpoke Bigg
item.media:description: A boy rides a donkey near one of the batteries of Israel’s Iron Dome missile defense system in the southern Negev desert on Sunday.

item.title: Iran’s Strike on Israel Creates Military Uncertainty, Diplomatic Opportunity
item.description: Analysts feared Iran’s strikes might set off a wider war. But with Israel still weighing its response, the attack’s military and diplomatic consequences have yet to be determined.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:description: A billboard showing Iranian missiles, on a road in Tehran on Monday.

item.title: Al Gore Thinks Trump Will Lose and Climate Activists Will Triumph
item.description: Mr. Gore spoke at a climate leadership conference hosted by his nonprofit organization.
item.dc:creator: Cara Buckley
item.media:credit: Calla Kessler for The New York Times

item.title: Netanyahu Weighs Response to Iran, Wary of Alienating Biden
item.description: Its options range from striking Iran openly and forcefully to doing nothing at all. One factor to weigh is that the huge aerial attack did little damage.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: An Israeli army vehicle headed toward Gaza on Monday.

item.title: With Nuclear Deal Dead, Containing Iran Grows More Fraught
item.description: The U.S., Europe, Russia and China worked together on a 2015 deal to limit Iran’s nuclear program. The arrangement’s unraveling and the spike in superpower tensions make this a dangerous moment.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: With the latest escalation of tensions between Iran and Israel, President Biden’s political opponents are now blaming the administration for having not taken a tougher line in recent years against Iran.

item.title: In Australia, a Validation of Sorts for Brittany Higgins
item.description: More than three years after Brittany Higgins went public with her claim of rape, her case reached a conclusion of sorts.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:description: Bruce Lehrmann leaving court in Sydney, Australia, on Monday.

item.title: Scientists Predict Most Extensive Coral Bleaching Event on Record
item.description: Rising sea temperatures around the planet have caused a bleaching event that is expected to be the most extensive on record.
item.dc:creator: Catrin Einhorn
item.media:description: Bleached coral off the Keppel Islands, Australia, at the southern end of the Great Barrier Reef, last month.

item.title: Tesla Will Lay Off More Than 10% of Global Workforce
item.description: Along with the departure of two senior executives, the cuts added to signs of turmoil at the electric car company.
item.dc:creator: Jack Ewing
item.media:credit: Philip Cheung for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tesla reported a decline in sales this month that caught investors off guard.
